required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Acute Consumption of Breakfast Meals With Black Walnut, English Walnuts, or no Nuts

brief_summary.textblock: Walnuts are a nutrient dense food, but most health research is on English walnuts (EW). Black walnuts (BW) contain a different antioxidant and fatty acid profile, and more protein, compared to EW. The purpose of the study was to compare postprandial responses following the consumption of 3 breakfast meals containing either butter (control), BW, or EW.

detailed_description.textblock:
This study was a randomized, double-blind control trial consisting of 3 study visits for 3 different treatments. The treatments were high-fat breakfast muffins containing either butter (control), black walnuts, or English walnuts. The investigators recruited healthy, normal-weight adults between the ages of 15 and 45y. Study visits were completed in a random order with at least 72 hours between each visit. Anthropometrics, questionnaires, and fasting and postprandial blood samples were collected at each visit.
Hypothesis: The walnut-containing meals would mitigate post-meal increases in glucose, insulin, triglycerides (TG), and lipid peroxidation while improving all measures of subjective appetite and TAC compared to the traditional meal without nuts.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in triglycerides (TG) and glucose responses
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 3 hours postprandially
Change from baseline to 3 hours postprandially
primary_outcome.description: Malondialdehyde (MDA) (uM) measured via Thiobarbituric acid reactive substances (TBARS) assay

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 3 hours postprandially
primary_outcome.description: Total antioxidant capacity (uM trolox equivalents) measured via Oxygen Radical Absorbance Capacity (ORAC) assay.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 3 hours postprandially

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in angiopoietin-like proteins-3 (ANGPTL3) and -4 (ANGPTL4) responses
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 3 hours postprandially

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in hunger and satiety responses
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline to 3 hours postprandially
secondary_outcome.description: Hunger, fullness, prospective consumption, and desire to eat measured via a Visual Analog Scale (VAS) (mm). The range of scores on the continuous VAS is 0-100 mm. Zero represents no hunger, fullness, prospective consumption, and desire to eat, while 100 represents the greatest feeling of these outcomes.

arm_group.description: Participants in this group received a traditional muffin with butter as the predominant source of fat.
Participants in this group received a muffin in which part of the butter was substituted out for black walnuts.
Participants in this group received a muffin in which part of the butter was substituted out for English walnuts.

intervention.description: Participants in this group received a traditional muffin with butter as the predominant source of fat.
Participants in this group received a muffin in which part of the butter was substituted out for black walnuts.
Participants in this group received a muffin in which part of the butter was substituted out for English walnuts.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy adult men and women
- Normal-weight (body mass index = 18-24.9kg/m2)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Allergies to test meal ingredients (gluten, eggs, or nuts)
- Medication/supplement usage
- Chronic disease
- Pregnancy or plans to become pregnant
- Special diets
- Tobacco use

facility.name: University of Georgia - Department of Foods and Nutrition & Department of Food Science and Technology

responsible_party.investigator_title: Professor and Director of UGA Obesity Initiative
